abstracts.cdata!:
The audit largely concurs with the
            Implementation Completion Report (ICR) ratings for both
            projects, on satisfactory project outcomes, (in spite of the
            ICR Review rating of moderately satisfactory), on modest
            institutional development impacts, and on a likely
            sustainability, in addition to the satisfactory ratings for
            both performances by the Bank and Borrower. The assessment
            shows the difficulties of implementing projects affected by
            a major exogenous shock, and a number of lessons can be
            drawn on how problems were addressed. To summarize, lessons
            suggest the following: 1) the formulation of realistic and
            measurable project objectives is crucial, and when there is
            a major restructuring of a project, the task team should
            take the opportunity to review the original objectives in
            light of changed circumstances; 2) Bank supervision
            arrangements should be realistic, and budgets should be
            higher when projects are decentralized, or spread over a
            wide area involving more than one implementing agency.
            Project design should take this into account; 3) covenants
            should not be imposed on authorities that do not have the
            legal power to carry out the commitment. Weak or open-ended
            conditionality should be avoided, and objectives should not
            be conflicting; and, 4) it is unwise to involve local,
            sub-national borrowers with the foreign exchange risks in
            unstable macroeconomic conditions, especially when their
            revenues are in the local currency.
